description: From Middle English aspre, from Old French aspre (modern French âpre), from Latin asper (“rough”).

adjectives.description: asper (comparative more asper, superlative most asper)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Rough or harsh; severe, stern, serious.
(phonetics, obsolete) Rough breathing; a mark (#) indicating that part of a word is aspirated, or pronounced with h before it.

description: From Middle English asper, from Middle French aspre or Italian aspro, both from Ancient Greek ἄσπρον (áspron), from neuter of ἄσπρος (áspros, “white”), from Latin asper (“rough, newly minted”).

entries.meaning: (historical) Any one of several small coins, circulated around the eastern Mediterranean area from the 12th to 17th centuries.
